page.title: 12South Denes Power Station
page.content: The South Denes Power Station was completed in 1957 as an oil fired one, although originally intended to be coal fired. The Denes site between the river Yare and the North Sea was an advantage for several reasons. In the first place fuel oil could be imported from the Thames Estuary refineries such as the Isle of Grain into the harbour from which water for steam raising could be obtained. The slightly warm water used in condensation could then be returned to the sea several hundred metres off shore. Peak power production was in the 1960s and early 70s supplying the London area at high demand times. In recent years production has declined, apart from high output during the Miner's Strike of 1984/5, and the station was finally closed down in Autumn 1985.
